final_topics.title: Solid Protocol Specification Development
final_topics.summary: These discussions center around the development, review, and clarification of the Solid Protocol specification. Key areas of focus include defining the protocol's relationship with LDP, standardizing features like WAC-Allow headers and N3 Patch, addressing concerns around URI handling and data modeling, and establishing conformance testing and processes for W3C standardization. The conversations also cover licensing, tooling, and architectural decisions related to Solid.

final_topics.title: Access Control and Authorization Models
final_topics.summary: These discussions revolve around various aspects of access control and authorization within the Solid ecosystem, with a primary focus on Web Access Control (WAC) and its alternatives like ACP and SAI. Key themes include the intricacies of WAC implementation, inheritance, and limitations, as well as proposals for improvements, extensions, and comparisons to other authorization models to address security concerns, data interoperability, and fine-grained permissioning. The conversations also cover practical aspects such as pod ownership, group management, application authorization, and the standardization of terminology and specifications.

final_topics.title: Solid-OIDC Authentication and Security
final_topics.summary: This topic cluster focuses on the technical aspects of Solid-OIDC authentication and security, including implementation challenges, specification compliance, and integration with technologies like FedCM and UMA. Discussions revolve around standardizing identity provider metadata retrieval, enhancing security through methods like HTTP signatures and RFC 9207 adoption, and exploring alternative authentication flows for various clients, including bots and autonomous agents. A key theme is ensuring secure and user-friendly authentication within the Solid ecosystem.

final_topics.title: Data Interoperability and Semantics
final_topics.summary: This topic cluster centers on achieving data interoperability within the Solid ecosystem and broader decentralized web, with a strong focus on semantic web technologies. Discussions cover a wide range of technical aspects including data modeling, schema languages (SHACL, ShEx), content negotiation, URI management, linked data signatures, and integration with technologies like ActivityPub, Verifiable Credentials, and decentralized identifiers (DIDs). A key theme is standardizing data discovery and access patterns to facilitate seamless application interoperability and robust data management within personal online data stores (Pods).

final_topics.title: Community Group Meeting Logistics
final_topics.summary: This topic cluster of 307 community groups centers around the logistics, governance, and administration of the Solid Community Group and related activities. Key themes include scheduling and coordinating meetings (both internal and joint with other groups like Credentials CG), managing meeting agendas and minutes, and discussing Solid specifications, project structure, and governance processes like chair elections and charter reviews. The groups also address technical discussions, administrative announcements, community updates, and platform-related issues like transitioning from Gitter to Matrix.

final_topics.title: Solid Pod Structure and Storage
final_topics.summary: This topic cluster centers on defining the structure, storage, and discovery mechanisms within Solid Pods. Key discussions revolve around standardizing container metadata, resource types, storage locations, and methods for reliable storage discovery given a WebID. The groups also address challenges around URI persistence, data ownership, and the interplay between application data, user data, and server implementations.

final_topics.title: Linked Data Notifications (PREP/LDN)
final_topics.summary: The conversation groups center on the development and implementation of Linked Data Notifications (LDN) and the Per Resource Events Protocol (PREP) within the Solid ecosystem. Key topics include protocol specifications (including WebSockets vs. Streaming HTTP), security considerations, the use of ActivityStreams, implementation challenges, and the establishment of task forces and special topic meetings to advance these technologies. Discussions also address the interplay between POST requests, RDF patches, and the resulting notification events within Solid.

final_topics.title: WebID Profile and Identity
final_topics.summary: The discussions revolve around defining, standardizing, and implementing WebIDs and their associated profiles within the Solid ecosystem. Key topics include the structure of WebID profiles, methods for profile discovery, the separation of technical vs. social data, and debates around one-hop vs. two-hop profile retrieval, as well as the use of DIDs and HTTP redirects. The conversations also address practical considerations like identity provider switching, security implications, and the alignment of WebID profiles with contact specifications.

final_topics.title: Solid Server Implementations
final_topics.summary: This topic cluster focuses on various aspects of Solid server implementations, ranging from specific server behaviors related to PUT/POST requests, LDP containers, and URI allocation, to broader discussions about spec conformance, authorization, and the challenges of deployment and domain management.  There's also significant interest in new server implementations (particularly in Rust), debugging existing implementations, and supporting application integration through features like webhooks and standardized APIs. The discussions highlight the complexities of building compliant and interoperable Solid servers.

final_topics.title: Data Querying and Discovery
final_topics.summary: The conversations revolve around strategies for data querying and discovery within the Solid ecosystem, heavily debating the merits and drawbacks of SPARQL versus dedicated search solutions like Apache Solr. Discussions cover topics like indexing, scalability, standardization of search APIs and service endpoints, multi-resource querying, security considerations, and alternatives like client-side indexing and HATEOAS for resource discovery.

final_topics.title: GitHub Management and Tooling
final_topics.summary: The groups focus on the management and maintenance of Solid's GitHub repositories, covering topics such as issue and pull request handling, repository restructuring, branch naming conventions, and tooling for monitoring and improving the ecosystem. Discussions also involve community guidelines enforcement, website content updates, and the process of transferring repositories to the Solid organization.

final_topics.title: Solid Vocabulary Management
final_topics.summary: The Solid community actively manages its vocabularies, addressing topics like best practices for RDF vocabulary usage, resolving conflicts in pull requests, and updating W3C namespaces. Discussions focus on creating a comprehensive Solid glossary, defining software vocabularies, and establishing processes for vocabulary curation and publication, including tool usage for validation and managing vocabulary URIs on w3.org.

final_topics.title: Data Modeling and RDF Formats
final_topics.summary: Contains 25 conversation groups about data modeling and rdf formats

final_topics.title: Data Synchronization and Replication
final_topics.summary: Contains 9 conversation groups about data synchronization and replication

final_topics.title: Legal Compliance and Security Considerations
final_topics.summary: The conversations cover a wide range of legal compliance and security considerations for Solid, including discussions around data privacy, application security limitations, and potential vulnerabilities. Specific topics addressed include the UK Online Safety Act, code of conduct enforcement, handling malicious requests, and the impact of various security measures like HTTP headers and authentication methods.
